content:
Just had this one in reverse mode, not a clue of the solution, so I had to come here to check it x)
Ofc, seems obvious now haha.
Nice idea, very challenging in reverse :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really new and brainstorming challenge

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good idea and well presented

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it but maybe too hard

Goal: I suggest to mention "the sum of 2 OPPOSITE faces", because on the other hand there could be variations (if we will look for 3 pairs of the same sums).

Let's check the Test1:
What if the sum is 10? 6+4, 5+?(5), 2+?(8).
What if the sum is 11? 6+5, 4+?(7), 2+?(9).

And now Test3:
What if the sum is 9? 6+3, 5+?(4), 0+?(9).

But if we will look for sums on opposite faces everything will fall into place.

P.S. It was hard for me to solve it quickly enough :(
So why this point and description prevent me from approve it..

Goal section
* Suggest to mention that each dice may or may not be a traditional dice with 1 to 6 as its faces.

Input section
* Please format "?" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Output section
* Please add "separated by a space".

Cases
* Please rearrange the cases so that there is at least one test where the leftmost digit and the rightmost digit are found in the same row (currently there are two such validators).

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback. I made the corrections.
Thank you for your feedback, you're right. I added that dices are cubic and that the sum of opposite faces is the same.

Thanks! I agree it might look harder that some other CoC puzzle. Dealing with unfolded 3D dices can be tricky. That's why I added the constraints on the shape. The idea is you can get the pair of opposite faces with minimal parsing, without having to deal with 3D at all.

Thanks! I hesitated to add reverse mode to this CoC, but I took the bet that most of us are familiar with unfolded dices. 
I agree if you don't see a dice right away, that might be tricky to guess the link between numbers :)
